did.unittitle: Appalachian Regional Commission records
did.abstract: The Appalachian Regional Commission (ARC) records (dated 1958-2018, undated; 329.46 cubic feet; 961 boxes) consist of the official records of the Appalachian Regional Commission since its inception in 1965 as well as reports of the projects funded by the ARC across the 13 states that make up the Appalachian Region.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to researchers by appointment.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection has been arranged by subject and format into eight series: Internal documents, State plans, Final project reports, Local development Districts, Appalachian Development Highway System assorted papers and documents, Audiovisual and two Addition series.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Passed by Congress in 1965, the Appalachian Regional Development Act established the Appalachian Regional Commission (ARC) to plan and manage economic development in the region. The Act defines the region as the entire state of West Virginia and parts of twelve other states--Alabama, Georgia, Kentucky, Maryland, Mississippi, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Tennessee and Virginia.

ARC concentrates its efforts in two major areas. The highway program, which annually receives about two-thirds of the ARC's funds, provides for construction of the Appalachian Development Highway System. The other major program, area development, provides grants for education and health care, water and sewer systems, housing, child development, enterprise development, natural resources development, and research on topics related to the region's economic development. Grants to undertake these projects are often combined with local and/or state funds.

The ARC is organized to ensure federal, state, and local participation. The Commission consists of fourteen members--the thirteen Appalachian governors and a Federal Co-Chair, appointed by the President. An executive director heads the Commission staff.

Staff members are paid jointly by the federal government and the states. Both Commission members and staff, through its member states, work with the Local Development Districts (LDDs), the multi-county planning and development agencies covering all 397 Appalachian counties.

The process of designing and funding ARC programs and projects is also structured to include all levels of government involvement. The ARC receives an annual appropriation from Congress and these funds are allocated by formula to the thirteen states. The governor of each state is responsible for developing an annual plan for meeting the ARC objectives, with input from the LDDs. The plan identifies specific projects that will receive ARC funds, usually in combination with other, federal, state, or local funds. Each state's development and project plan must be approved by the Commission.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: In the summer of 1989, the University of Kentucky Libraries contracted with the Appalachian Regional Commission as the permanent repository for the agency's library and archives. The library was integrated into the University's Appalachian Collection, specialized branch libraries, and the general collection, originally housed in the M.I. King Library but now located in Young Library.

The archives, consisting of the ARC's official records since its beginning in 1965, will be updated annually, and is housed in the University Libraries' Department of Special Collections and Digital Programs.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: 90M1: [Identification of item], Appalachian Regional Commission records, 1958-2018, undated, University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Appalachian Regional Commission (ARC) records (dated 1958-2018, undated; 329.46 cubic feet; 961 boxes) consist of the official records of the Appalachian Regional Commission since its inception in 1965 as well as reports of the projects funded by the ARC across the 13 states that make up the Appalachian Region.

The records are divided into eight series: Internal documents, State plans, Final project reports, Local development Districts, Appalachian Development Highway System assorted papers and documents, Audiovisual, 2020ms106 addition, and 2023ms095 addition. The Internal Documents reflect the ARC's daily operations and range from annual reports and official Commission meeting materials to files of background information on regional development and policy papers. The State Plans, submitted annually to the ARC, are each state's program development documentation and investment plans for its Appalachian counties. The Final Project Reports are those submitted by demonstration projects and programs funded, in whole or in part, by the ARC. And the Local Development Districts document the relationship between the ARC and the LDDs and the specific activities of the LDDs. Materials range from profiles of individual LDDs to reports on projects executed by the LDDs, which were funded by sources other than the ARC. In addition, the records contain audio-visual materials, oral history interviews conducted by Duke University, and a small photograph collection. The 2020ms106 addition contains internal documents, research and travel materials, and newspaper clippings primarily from the tenure of Earl F. Gohl as Federal Co-Chair.The 2023ms095 additon contains photographs and publications not found in the orignal accession from the tenure of Winifred A. Pizzano as Federal Co-Chair in the 1980s.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The physical rights to the materials in this collection are held by the University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center.

did.unittitle: Internal Documents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This section comprises approximately one-third of the ARC Archives and primarily reflects the daily operations of the ARC, as executed both by the staff and by the official Commission members. These documents are extensive in their scope, although not chronologically complete in every category. Topics covered include Commission meetings, policy, research reports, fiscal history, and the history of the Appalachian Regional Development Act. In addition, two headings describe the origins of the ARC: "Pre-ARC History" includes the documents of the President's Appalachian Regional Commission (PARC); and "Start-Up" contains the 1965 documents which were the blue-prints for ARC operations--from office procedures to policy-making.

did.unittitle: Annual Reports

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Beginning in 2003, ARC annual reports were combined with performance plans.

Appalachian Regional Development Acts (ARDA)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These materials provide a history of the ARDA, the legislation that created the ARC. Included are transcripts from congressional hearings, congressional committee reports and bills, and correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Included in these boxes are transcripts of meetings, minutes, and discussion papers. These materials document the official business of the Commission. Note that all meetings were held in Washington D.C. unless stated otherwise. Also, each item listed contains the meeting materials from that meeting unless stated otherwise.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This section contains a variety of materials (e.g. brochures, minutes, proceedings) about conferences and meetings either funded by ARC or those in which ARC participated, and, in some instances, both. For meetings where foficial Commission business was conducted see the previous section, "Commission Meeting Materials."

Federal Co-Chair's Files (Winifred A. Pizzano, 1982-1989)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Winifred A. Pizzano's career is represented by materials that reflect four separate stages culminating in her appointment as Federal Co-Chair of the Appalachian Regional Commission, confirmed by the U.S. Senate on September 24, 1982. Prior to that, she served for a year as deputy director of ACTION, the federal agency administering volunteer programs. She also was the director, from 1975-1981, of health care and social services for Arthur Young and Company, a research and development consulting firm located in Washington, D.C. Pizzano served from 1970-1975 as executive administrator for the Illinois Department of Public Health, Division of Emergency Medical Services in Chicago, where she helped establish a statewide trauma program.

Pizzano's papers are divided into ARC and Non-ARC materials. The ARC documents are the most extensive and comprehensive. They range from biographical materials to subject files covering topics such as education, employment, rural health policy, and technology transfer. Non-ARC materials consist of files from her employment prior to her ARC Federal Co-Chair appointment.

Fiscal History

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arranged topically, then chronologically by Fiscal Year (FY), these files include authorization, appropriation, and expenditure documents.

From FY 1969-1978 and 1990-forward budget requests were submitted to the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) by the Federal Co-Chair of ARC. These requests were submitted approximately 24 months prior to the FY start. For example FY 1969 was submitted in the fall of 1967 for a FY beginning date of October 1, 1969.

From 1967-forward budget requests were also submitted by the Appalachian Governors to the Senate and House Congressional Appropriations Committees 18-20 months prior to the beginning of the FY. For example, the FY 1969 request was sent to Congress in January-February of 1968 for a FY beginning date of October 1, 1969.

From 1967-1980 bound books of the Budget of the United States Appendix are available. These contain the President's recommendations to Congress on line items. After 1980, the President no longer included the ARC in his budget; final appropriations for the ARC came through Congressional authorization. However, beginning again in 1990, the ARC was included in the President's budget.
Following the budget documents are the reports for funds expended and carryover monies for each fiscal year. These are arranged chronologically, from 1966-current.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These materials document investigations of ARC practices or programs by federal government offices or private consultants. In general, these were not evaluations initiated by the ARC and, as a group, can be viewed as a partial record of ARC's public accountability. For overall evaluations of the ARC, initiated and/or conducted by the ARC, see sections under "Program and Project Files": 1970 Evaluation, Program Design, and Regional Plan. For analyses of specific programs or projects initiated by the ARC, see Final Project Reports--Program Analyses.

Appalachian Community Service Network (ACSN)-Board Meeting Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Appalachian Community Service Network is a successor to the Appalachian Education Satellite Project (AESP), which was first established in the mid-1960's for telecasting graduate courses to receiving sites in eight Appalachian States. Funded, in part, by the ARC and the National Institute of Education, ACSN continued to produce and broadcast educational programming via cable television.
These materials reflect primarily the relationship between the ARC and ACSN in the early 1980's.

The Learning Channel (TLC)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Learning Channel (TLC) is a national cable television service offering adult learning and information services. Now a private enterprise, TLC's origin is in the government-based Appalachian Community Service Network of the early 1970s. TLC has programming in four major areas: business and career development, college telecourses, personal enrichment, and parenting and teaching. It has over four million viewers. The materials included are the promotional and press kits produced by The Learning Channel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These files illustrate the multiple ways in which the ARC often approached a topic or concern.

The Black Appalachian Commission (BAC) files consist mainly of correspondence between the ARC and BAC; BAC, formed in 1970, challenged the ARC to be responsive to the needs of African Americans in the region.
The materials in the "Black Child Development Institute" file document a case of the ARC acting as a go-between for the region's citizens and other federal funding agencies.
Folders 4 and 5 are statistical compilations on topics for which regional data is difficult, if not impossible, to find.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The ARC identified about 90 counties in various states which were "distressed and underdeveloped" in 1981. These counties, located mainly in Central Appalachia, became eligible for special funding consideration in 1983 when the Commission's "Finish-Up Program" was accepted by Congress as part of the revised ARC program policies.
This program assists counties in developing safe water and sewage systems. [See Finish-Up, Boxes 170-172, for related materials]

A large part of this evaluation was conducted by independent evaluators who, in turn, submitted their work to an independent evaluation panel for review prior to its submission to the Commission.

Finish-Up

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Finish-Up Program was the ARC's response to the Reagan Administration's 1980 plan to cease funding support for all ARC non-highway projects and to transfer highway projects to the Department of Transportation. After each state conducted studies focusing on the projected impact of recession and hearings were conducted in 1982, legislation was passed extending the Appalachian Regional Development Act. It was a crucial time, however, and these files reflect the crisis.

The categories from 1980-1983 include Congressional District Impact Statements from each member state, Futures Material, Hearings, Ideas, Legislation and General. "Futures Material" contains notes for and rough drafts of projected yearly plans. "Ideas" contains material such as ARC staff suggestions and a work program for the report to Congress; "Hearings" contains material such as anticipated Congressional questions regarding programs and in-depth responses, and statements given during the 1982 hearings by Senators, Governors, and witnesses.

These documents portray the time and effort expended towards fiscal survival and redirecting Commission program priorities to emphasize highway completion. The Finish-Up strategy was projected for 3-5 years, but the ARC succeeded in maintaining diminished but ongoing Congressional funding support and the mandate to disband it was removed.

Floods

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These files document the flood recovery and control efforts of the ARC, the U. S. Army Corps of Engineers (USCOE), the National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA); and an ARC field effort, the Central Appalachia Development Project (CADP).

did.unittitle: Tug Fork Project

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Tug Fork Project was a cooperative effort between the USCOE, CADP, and the ARC, to provide flood control and recovery, along with housing and economic development, to the Tug Fork Region of Kentucky, Virginia and West Virginia.

This project was begun as a result of Congressional action after the Corps of Engineers reported in 1970 on the flooding conditions in the region. The 1974 Water Resources Development Act authorized the Corps of Engineers to develop a comprehensive flood protection plan for the Tug Valley. The USCOE contracted with ABT Associates, Inc. of Cambridge, Massachusetts, to do detailed historical, demographic, economic and land use studies. The USCOE was also responsible for dredging stream beds, dam construction and repair, plus housing/business relocation above the flood plain. The CADP provided local community contact with the USCOE and assisted in obtaining right of entry permission where needed. They also coordinated the activities of planning groups. The ARC supervised and acted as liaison for the project.

Central Appalachia Development Project (CADP)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The CADP was begun in 1977 to assist in identifying and implementing solutions to flood related problems in 45 central Appalachian counties. These counties were declared disaster areas as a result of floods during the spring of 1977. The counties were located in Kentucky, Tennessee, Virginia and West Virginia. Funding for a three year period was provided by the ARC. These activities were in addition to the Tug Fork Project and done cooperatively with the USCOE.

Highway Studies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As this collection has grown significantly in terms of the materials in regard to the Appalachian Development Highway System, it has since become its own section. The materials that used to be here can now be located under the heading "Appalachian Development Highway System," following the Local Development Districts. Individual final reports can also be found in the "Final Project Reports" section, under both individual states and regional.

did.unittitle: Program Design

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Program Design Project was an attempt to evaluate the ARC's impact during its first seven years and to make plans for future programs based on the evaluation. Conducted from 1972-1975, the bulk of the study was done in 1973-1974.

The ARC staff solicited program assessments from outsiders who were familiar with the programs, including mayors, Local Development District (LDD) staff and Board members, and former managers of ARC-funded projects. These reports and opinions were used by staff in evaluating the program and planning future program emphases.
The files are arranged by topic, e.g. Housing, Education, Environment, etc. There are also "General" files and several files from an oversight committee.

The "General" files contain Commission correspondence between ARC staff, state officials and Commission members which gives overviews of meetings, future plans and reports on post-program design activities.

The Institutional Development Strategy subcommittee, composed of appointed Commission members and staff, acted as an oversight committee to coordinate the time schedules for the topical program activities. They also served as liaison for the Executive Director and Federal Co-chairs, and compiled the individual reports into summary documents.
These records were collected by ARC staff member, Paige Ingraham.

Regional Plan

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mandated by Congressional amendments to the ARDA in 1975, the ARC was directed to assess the changing conditions in the Region occurring since 1965, and to prepare an overall Regional Plan defining goals, objectives, and priorities. Prior to 1975, the ARC's focus on planning was to assist the states in their annual development plans and then bring each plan together under one cover: Appalachian Plan.

These materials document the process of creating a coordinated overall regional plan encompassing "local, state, and federal development efforts for the best use of public funds and the stimulation of private investment for development." The Plan's aim was to provide regional guidance in planning as well as a policy framework for the ARC program.

The making of the Regional Plan was a form of self-study and evaluation for the ARC. See "1970 Evaluation' (Boxes 167-169) and "Program Design" (Boxes 187-195), also in this section, for earlier evaluations to compare how methods varied.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In 1964, System Development Corporation (SDC) was contracted to set up guidelines for the newly proposed ARC. The following folders contain documents drawn up by the SDC including reports from organizational meetings, manuals outlining the framework for the Commission, personnel policies, budget recommendations, and procedures for program and project implementation.

March 3, 1965-April 19, 1965
July 16, 1965-September 1965
N.d.
States' Representative Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These files of the States' Representative to the ARC, 1965-1977, primarily cover the activities of John D. Whisman, who was the first appointed States' Representative. This position grew out of his work with the Eastern Kentucky Regional Planning Commission, a group which was instrumental in the formation of the ARC.

The "General" files include calendars, letters, reports on policy, and program development and implementation reflecting areas of interest such as highway construction, health care, water resources, forestry and child development. During the years 1972-1974, these files gradually portray a shift in Whisman's activities towards increased participation in conferences as an expert in regional development and travel to meetings. Also included are 1974 newspaper articles critical of Whisman followed by his responses to the Appalachian Governors, and the 1975 legislation passed that changed the authority of the States' Representative position.
The "Travel" files contain materials such as travel vouchers, itineraries, and receipts and/or copies of receipts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Collected primarily by former ARC staff member, Paige Ingraham, Associate Director of State and Local Administration, these files can be viewed as research and background materials for policies, programs, and projects considered by and, in some cases, implemented by the ARC.

did.unittitle: Conference on Balanced National Growth

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These files document the preliminary discussions, agenda, position papers, and findings of the Conference on Balanced National Growth held in January 1978, sponsored by the White House. In addition, materials from pre-conference sessions, which were forums for citizens input, are included.
The White House Conference materials complement the National Growth Policy Development files located in Boxes 248-249.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These documents, assembled over a 20-year period beginning in 1960, originate from many different Federal agencies. They reflect the differences in opinions, priorities and strategies within the Federal Government. Filed in chronological order, these files provide a historical perspective on economic development issues in the U.S., 1960-1980.

Housing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: he ARC has, historically, emphasized two objectives in housing: stimulate use of federal housing programs and assist in establishing state housing programs. These files, covering 1966-1974, include information on early ARC efforts to address housing issues; Section 207 amendment of the Appalachian Regional Development Act; Urban America, whose mandate was to ameliorate urban substandard housing; the model program "New Towns"; participating state files containing reports and correspondence; and legislation.

In 1967, Congress authorized the ARC to provide housing assistance by making loans and grants for planning and by obtaining insured mortgages through the National Housing Act. The mandate was broadened in 1971 with the Section 207 amendment. It provided monies for site development and off-site improvement grants for housing projects including building infrastructures--water lines, sewers, and roads to housing sites. Section 207 also provided technical assistance such as the establishment of housing finance agencies. Urban America was contracted to study Kentucky and West Virginia, targeted because of their severe housing problems. This study resulted in legislation creating the West Virginia Housing Development Fund. Other states such as Kentucky and Georgia followed with the model program, New Towns, incorporating ideas from the HUD prototype of existing planned towns--New Communities in Selected European Countries.

President's Reorganization Project (PRP)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The PRP was an attempt by President Jimmy Carter in 1977-78 to revamp the federal administrative bureaucracy. He aimed to streamline organizations, standardize applications and federal guidelines for grants, and encourage local decision-making in federal programs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Each fiscal year states submitted documents to the ARC outlining a plan of fiscal management and program development for its Appalachian counties. This section is arranged alphabetically by state and further subdivided chronologically. The materials for each state and year vary considerably; they range from correspondence to drafts of the comprehensive state plan, and from specific program plans (e.g. health, economic, child development) to plans submitted for only the Appalachian portion of a state. Each state is not chronologically complete. Note that abstracts and summaries of State Plans are located in Boxes 355-356.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: ike "Internal Documents", this section comprises approximately one-third of the ARC Archives. It is divided into three categories: project reports that are site-specific and, therefore, arranged by state; those that are regional in scope; and finally, "Program Analyses", reports in which the main purpose was evaluation.

Project reports were placed in this section if, somewhere on the document, funding credit is given to the ARC or if an ARC contract number appears on the item. Other project reports are located in the last section, Local Development Districts--Publications and Reports (See Boxes 660-771).
Each entry is arranged:
Title/ author; date. Project number (if available)

Often the reports have only contract numbers (e.g. 66-100) which were simply accession numbers for the ARC. These numbers are not included in an entry. Project numbers usually, but not always, take the form: KY-0000-00-I-201-0000. The first two letters indicate the general source of money from which the funding came-- in this example, the money originated from funds allocated to Kentucky projects; the number, 201, represents the program category, "Highways". Since this entire inventory can be keyword searched, it is possible for a researcher to see all project reports that fall into a particular program category, if that report has a project number.
All reports which are marked "OVERSIZE" refer to the Box and Folder number where that item is located.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These ARC-generated reports were used by ARC staff for their own information in program planning or to educate Appalachian Governors' staff or Congressional staff about specific issues. In some cases, Congress requested the ARC to study a particular topic and produce a report. Each report is about one topic (e.g. coal, unemployment, migration) and is regional in scope. A few reports while not necessarily financed by the ARC (e.g. certain highway studies) have been included here because of their direct relationship to ARC programs and projects.

Program Analyses

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These documents are also the products of ARC-financed research, conducted both internally and externally. The reports were used to create programs and assess program development, planning and execution. While reports in the two preceding categories often have evaluative elements, these reports tend to be specifically concentrated on the assessment of broader ARC programming and goals, rather than on a particular project.

Local Development Districts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arranged by topics, these materials date primarily from the late 1960s to the mid-1970s. Originally collected by former ARC staff member, Paige Ingraham, these are documents mainly generated by the ARC and sent to the LDD's as guidelines. The LDD's documentation of compliance is outlined in the section, "LDD Profiles (1973)", Boxes 635-652.

The files also contain information about LDD practices in non-Appalachian states including Governor's executive orders, regional planning documents and establishment legislation. Also included are "Establishment Documents" for ARC-LDD's, grouped by state. These contain legislation and executive orders on the state and local level which provided guidelines for LDD organization and bylaws for ARC-LDD's.

did.unittitle: Background Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

Originally collected by former ARC staff member, Paige Ingraham, these are documents mainly generated by the ARC and sent to the LDD's as guidelines. The LDD's documentation of compliance is outlined in the section, "LDD Profiles (1973)", Boxes 635-652.
The files also contain information about LDD practices in non-Appalachian states including Governor's executive orders, regional planning documents and establishment legislation.

Also included are "Establishment Documents" for ARC-LDD's, grouped by state. These contain legislation and executive orders on the state and local level which provided guidelines for LDD organization and bylaws for ARC-LDD's.

Conferences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The purpose of these conferences was to discuss current trends and generate new ideas in economic and social development; and to develop working relationships between ARC staff and LDD personnel.
Initially held twice a year, and later, annually, the conferences convened in Washington D.C., unless otherwise noted.

1973-1974 Profiles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Each state begins with files from the state office containing general, statewide information and correspondence, followed by a profile of each LDD covering topics such as: Legislation, Administration, Newsletters, Annual Reports, and Budgets.

While these documents profile the districts, they differ greatly from the 1983-1984 profiles. These earlier documents were not systematically assembled by the LDD's and sent to the ARC, but were compiled by ARC staff to look at the functioning of the LDD's.
Not all LDD's in the ARC region are profiled, and not all LDD's have the same topical headings.
These files are arranged alphabetically by state, by LDD within the state and by topic within the District.

1984-1985 Profiles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: All of the profiles have the same basic construction beginning with a map of the Appalachian region, with color identifying the area covered by the profile. The next heading is "General Information" including Chair, Executive Director, Congressional Delegations and a breakdown of LDD Administrative funding for the current fiscal year, and ARC funding since 1965. Two survey responses make up the next category: A 1984 ARC-LDD survey and the NARC (National Association of Regional Councils) Survey of Regional Activities. Lists of board and staff members, and projects funded by the ARC make up the next two divisions. The "Newsletter" category also contains pamphlets and brochures. The last three sections are "Socio-Economic Data", "Other Information" and a "Transition Statement" proposing a survival plan in the event that the ARC is terminated.
The profiles are arranged alphabetically by state and then by development district. The date on each folder entry signifies when that profile was last updated.

Publications and Reports

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These are documents generated by the LDD's in each state, or by a state-wide office overseeing and coordinating the LDD's. Annual reports, informational documents for local governments, and project reports are included. The project reports in this category differ from those in "Final Project Reports", Boxes 357-539. Generally, these projects were funded by federal agencies other than the ARC, or a state agency; and, an ARC contract number does not appear on the item so it was assumed that the ARC did not fund the project. However, since contractors did not always adhere to uniform formats in their reports, it is possible that documents in this section were actually funded by the ARC.

Arranged alphabetically by state, then by district, the documents are in chronological order within each district. Reports which are multi-district or statewide follow the district subdivisions for each state.
All publications that are designated "Oversize" are located in the last box in the series (See Box 772).

Appalachian Development Highway System (ADHS) Assorted Papers and Documents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Development of an adequate transportation system is the Commission's first priority in improving the Region's economy. The Appalachian Development Highway System (ADHS) was designed to open up isolated areas so that economic development could occur. The ADHS connects at strategic points to interstate highways and is laid out so that most of the Region's population is no more than thirty minutes away from either an interstate or an Appalachian highway. At the end of FY 2010, of the 3,090 miles authorized to be improved, 2,715.1 were completed or under construction.
Periodic studies of the cost to complete the highway system were developed to be a basis for allocation of authorized and appropriated funds among the states.

FHWA Project Status Reports

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These boxes contain the Fiscal Management Information System (FMIS) M44A reports generated by the Federal Highway Administration, providing comprehensive reports of the status of the highway project and the current status of and money allocated to each section. Each M44A report is split into two separate groupings: the larger development projects and the access roads to connect communities to the planned highways.

Pikeville Open Cut Project

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The "Open Cut" project relocated the Levisa Fork of the Big Sandy River to aid in flood control, provide flat land for business and residential development, and provide fill for an airport. Also see State Specific Highway Papers and Plans, Kentucky, for more materials.

1998 ADHS Highway Safety Study

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In 1997, Congress requested that the ADHS conduct a highway safety study to verify their claim that finishing the unconstructed sections of the highways would help reduce the amount of accidents, and how best to allocate money to lower the number of accidents available. The following materials are split into two sections: the "Materials" section containing correspondence, handwritten notes, and drafts of the report, and the "State Data" section containing the state transportation departments' reports on the number of accidents in the area covered by the ADHS.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 2020ms106 addition series (dated 1994-2018, undated; 4.23 cubic feet; 5 boxes) comprise correspondence, speeches, travel details, publications, and research materials used by the ARC. Also includes grants, photographs, newspaper and online articles, and documents produced by allied organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
